title: LADR
text:
Website for learning Linear Algebra Done Right (LADR) 1. The book is open access and LADR4e.pdf is available.
Custom callouts are used on this website 2. The custom.scss must be referred in the YAML.

title: VectorSpaces
text:
definition: vector space


A \(vector space\) is a set \(V\) alond with an addition on V and a scalar multiplication on V such that the following properties hold.
\(\textbf{1. commutativity}\)
\(u+v = v+ u\) for all \(u,v \in V\)
\(\textbf{2. associativity}\)
\((u+v)+w = v+(u+w)\) and \((ab)v = a(bv)\) for all \(u,v,w \in V\) and for all \(a,b \in F\).
\(\textbf{3. additive identity}\)
There exists an element \(0 \in V\) such that \(v + 0 = v\) for all \(v \in V\).
\(\textbf{4. additive inverse}\)
For every \(v \in V\) there exists \(w \in V\) such that \(v+w=0\).
\(\textbf{5. multiplicative identity}\)
\(1v = v\) for all \(v \in V\)
\(\textbf{6. distributive properties}\)
\(a(u+v) = au+av\) amd \((a+b)v = av+bv\) for all \(a,b \in F\) and \(u,v \in V\).

\(\textbf{2. associativity}\)

title: VectorSpaces
text:
definition: vector



Elements of a vector space are called vectors or points.
A vector or point in \(\mathbb{R^n}\) is \((x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)\) where \(x_k \in \mathbb{R}\) for \(k=1,2,\ldots,n.\)
The set of all lists of vectors of length \(n\) is \(\mathbb{R^n}\)
If this set obeys the properties of a vector space then the set is a vector space over \(\mathbb{R}\)





1.20 definition: vector space


A vector space is a set \(V\) along with an addition and scalar multiplication on \(V\) such that the following properties hold.
1. commutativity
\(u+v = v+ u\) for all \(u,v \in V\)
2. associativity
\((u+v)+w = v+(u+w)\) and \((ab)v = a(bv)\) for all \(u,v,w \in V\) and for all \(a,b \in F\).
3. additive identity
There exists an element \(0 \in V\) such that \(v + 0 = v\) for all \(v \in V\).
4. additive inverse
For every \(v \in V\) there exists \(w \in V\) such that \(v+w=0\).
5. multiplicative identity
\(1v = v\) for all \(v \in V\)
6. distributive properties
\(a(u+v) = au+av\) and \((a+b)v = av+bv\) for all \(a,b \in F\) and \(u,v \in V\).


A key difference between field and vector space is the multiplication by a scalar in the case of vectors. “Multiplication” between vectors is not defined.
Examples: Vector spaces:
\(\mathbb{R}\) - real vector space over \(\mathbb{R}\)
\(\mathbb{C}\) - complex vector space over \(\mathbb{C}\)
\(\mathbb{F}^n\) - finite dimensional vector space over \(\mathbb{F}\)
\(\mathbb{F}^\infty\) - infinite vector space over \(\mathbb{F}\)
\(\mathbb{F}^S\) - the set of functions from \(S\) to \(F\)

title: WebLADR
text:
Usage
::::: defn
::: defn-head
definition: vector space
:::

::: defn-body
A $vector space$ is a set $V$ alond with an addition on V and a scalar multiplication on V such that the following properties hold.

$\textbf{commutativity}$

$u+v = v+ u$ for all $u,v \in V$

$\textbf{associativity}$

$(u+v)+w = v+(u+w)$ and $(ab)v = a(bv)$ for all $u,v,w \in V$ and for all $a,b \in F$.
:::
:::::


definition: vector space


A \(vector space\) is a set \(V\) alond with an addition on V and a scalar multiplication on V such that the following properties hold.
\(\textbf{commutativity}\)
\(u+v = v+ u\) for all \(u,v \in V\)
\(\textbf{associativity}\)
\((u+v)+w = v+(u+w)\) and \((ab)v = a(bv)\) for all \(u,v,w \in V\) and for all \(a,b \in F\).


::::: prop
  ::: prop-head
  ::: prop-body
:::::


conditions for subspace


A subset \(U\) of \(V\) is a subspace of \(V\) if and only if \(U\) satisfies the following three conditions.
\(\textbf{additive identity}\)
\(0 \in U\)
\(\textbf{closed under addition}\)
\(u, w \in U\) implies \(u+w \in U\).
\(\textbf{closed under scalar multiplication}\)
\(a \in F\) and \(u \in U\) implies \(au \in U\)

title: Subspaces
text:
1.20 definition: subspace


A subset \(U\) of \(V\) is called a subspace of \(V\) if \(U\) is also a vector space with the same additive identity, addition and scalar multiplication as on \(V\).




1.34 conditions for a subspace


A subset \(U\) of \(V\) is a subspace of \(V\) if and only if \(U\) satisfies the following three conditions.
additive identity
\(0 \in U\)
closed under addition
\(u,w \in U\) implies \(u+w \in U\)
closed under scalar multiplication
\(a \in F\) and \(u \in U\) implies \(au \in U\)


Examples: subspaces

The set of continuous real valued functions on the interval [0,1] is a subspace of \(\mathbb{R}^{[0,1]}\)
the set of differentiable real-valued functions on \(\mathbb{R}\) is a subspace of \(\mathbb{R}^{R}\)
the set of all sequences of complex numbers with limit 0 is a subspace of \(\mathbb{C}^\infty\).


Sums of Subspaces


1.20 definition: sum of subspace


Suppose \(V_1,\ldots,V_m\) are subspaces of \(V\). The sum of \(V_1,\ldots,V_m\), denoted by \(V_1+\ldots+V_m\), is the set of all possible sums of elements of \(V_1,\ldots,V_m\). More precisely, \[
V_1+\ldots,+V_m = \{v_1+\cdots+v_m : v_1 \in V,\ldots,v_m \in V_m\}
\]


Examples of sum of subspaces

a sum of subspaces of \(\mathbb{F}^3\)

If U is the set of elements of \(\mathbb{F}^3\) whose second and third coordinates equal 0, and W is the set of elements of \(\mathbb{F}^3\) whose first and third coordinates equal 0: \[
U = \{(x,0,0) \in \mathbb{F}^3: x \in \mathbb{F}\} \text{ and }
W = \{(0,y,0) \in \mathbb{F}^3: y \in \mathbb{F}\}
\] then, \[
U + W = \{(x,y,0) \in \mathbb{F}^3) : x,y \in \mathbb{F}\}
\]


Direct sums


1.20 definition: direct sum, \(\oplus\)


Suppose \(V_1,\ldots,V_m\) are subspaces of \(V\).

The sum of \(V_1+\cdots+V_m\), is called a direct sum if each element \(V_1+\cdots+V_m\) can be written in only one way as a sum \(v_1+\cdots+v_m\), where each \(v_k \in V_k\).
If \(V_1+\cdots+V_m\) is a direct sum, then \(V_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus V_m\) denotes \(V_1+\cdots+V_m\), with the \(\oplus\) notation serving as an indication that this is a direct sum.



Examples of direct sum \(\oplus\)

a sum of subspaces of \(\mathbb{F}^3\)

If U is ths subspace of \(\mathbb{F}^3\) whose second and third coordinates equal 0, and W is the set of elements of \(\mathbb{F}^3\) whose first and third coordinates equal 0: \[
U = \{(x,0,0) \in \mathbb{F}^3: x \in \mathbb{F}\} \text{ and }
W = \{(0,y,0) \in \mathbb{F}^3: y \in \mathbb{F}\}
\] then, \[
U + W = \{(x,y,0) \in \mathbb{F}^3) : x,y \in \mathbb{F}\}
\]

title: FiniteVSpaces
text:
2.4 definition: span


The set of all linear combinations of a list of vectors \(v_1, \ldots, v_m\) in \(V\) is call the span of \(v_1, \ldots, v_m\), denoted by span(\(v_1, \ldots, v_m\)). In other workds \[
span(v_1, \ldots, v_m) = (av_1+\ldots+a_m v_m : a_1,\ldots,a_m \in \mathbb{F})
\] The span of the empty list () is defined to be (0).





2.4 definition: polynomial, \(\mathbb{P(F)}\)


The set of all linear combinations of a list of vectors \(v_1, \ldots, v_m\) in \(V\) is call the span of \(v_1, \ldots, v_m\), denoted by span(\(v_1, \ldots, v_m\)). In other workds \[
span(v_1, \ldots, v_m) = (av_1+\ldots+a_m v_m : a_1,\ldots,a_m \in \mathbb{F})
\] The span of the empty list () is defined to be (0).
